lesson.title: Planning Phase
lesson.summary: In order to design a dashboard that meets our users needs we need to first understand what they are after and what are their pain points. Early discussions are critical in the planning phase.

atoms.text:
## Fun Fact!
Robert Crocker is one of our international expert instructors. We are very excited that he was able to complete his course in his current location: Chile! 

We hope you enjoy this course with Robert. He brings a great deal of experience and expertise in designing dashboards, and we are excited that in this course, he is sharing his best practices with our students.

## Welcome to the Course

Welcome to this course on Dashboard Design, taught by our expert instructor, Robert Crocker. In this course, you will be learning about dashboard design. The principles of dashboard design can be applied to practically any dashboard you ever create, whether it is in Excel, Tableau or any other platform.

## Course Outline
### Lesson 1: Planning Phase
In this lesson, Robert will be walking us through the various goals and tasks of the design phase. By the end of this lesson, you will have learned and practiced asking your audience important questions about what are their needs and expectations from the dashboard. You will know how to understand the pain points of the business stakeholder as well as the priorities the dashboard should be addressing. This foundation sets up the dashboard design process very nicely.

### Lesson 2: Design Phase
In this lesson, Robert introduces us the to concept of graphicacy. You will learn about how to make chart choices, keep visual hierarchy in mind. You will get busy with creating doodles or early designs, followed by designing a wireframe for your dashboard, and finally building a prototype for the dashboard. You will learn about common layouts, alignment guidelines. This interim step for creating dashboard prototype is important best practice for when you are developing a dashboard. for a client or organization.

### Lesson 3: Polishing Dashboard for Production
Finally, in lesson 3, Robert will walk us through the final polishing process for the dashboard. This will include discussion and actual hands-on practice with color schemes, encoding, paying attention to interactivity and annotations. Robert will also introduce us to important concepts and best practices that are key to creating visually compelling dashboards.

We are SO excited about the dashboard you will be building as part of this course!

atoms.title: Link to IDEO quote
atoms.text:
Here is the link to the IDEO quote in the slides above: https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/innovation __Why knowing the audience is important?__
It is important to know the audience for whom you are developing the dashboard. The dashboard is designing a solution for people with problems, so it is important that you are creating a product, application or service that will create solutions they will want to use.

atoms.title: Strategic - tactical client
atoms.text:
One way to classify your audience is by the time dimension of when they make decisions. This creates two types of classifications: strategic VS tactical. The distinction between these roles is __how much information your target audience needs__ to take into account __when making a decision__.
__Strategic audiences__ is generally looking for an overview of their business and the general direction in which we’re heading. Most people in strategic positions won’t have the time or need to get into the nitty gritty details of the data.

__Tactical audiences__ need their data to be fresh and flowing. This means the data they need in order to make their decisions are current, which also means there should be a clear indication on the dashboards about the last time the data was refreshed and potentially how long before the next refresh happens. Tactical audiences make decisions quickly and the decimal point could very well matter.

atoms.title: link to hierarchy image with strategic + client
atoms.caption: Strategic_tactical dashboards_Audience types

atoms.text:
# Exercise 1: Strategic or Tactical Audience?

Look through the audiences described below and decide if they are strategic or tactical. Then describe how that might affect the dashboard you are designing.

# Solution:

### Persona 1
The answer is **Tactical** because Gabriel is looking to take action today. It is not strategic because this isn’t a decision she’s weighing heavily against several other factors over a large window of time.

### Persona 2
The answer is **Strategic** because no decisions are going to be made. It’s more for talking points than anything else. On the other hand, if the dashboard was informing what ads were going to be displayed or which stories would be written the day after, then it would be tactical.

### Persona 3
The answer is **Strategic** because no one is being asked to immediately take action on this information. On the other hand, if guests were asked to use the information to vote on policy, donate as certain amount of money or take any other sort of action before walking away, then we might be looking at a tactical dashboard.

atoms.title: Audience motivations
atoms.text:
### Audience motivations can be summarized into: * Incentives * Deadlines * Value the dashboard adds * Pain points ### Sample questions to ask to learn the following topics: __Audience background:__
* Did they get a degree relative to the work their doing today? * Have they focused their career in any particular industry or domain? * What kind of work do they most enjoy doing and would want to do more of? * What kind of work do they despise and would like to avoid? * Who are the main stakeholders? * How technical are the users? * Have the key metrics already been defined? __Value the dashboard adds:__ * Explore questions about the context of the dashboard. * What drove this project to start now? * Can you tell me how you imagine the dashboard being used in your work setting? * Has anyone attempted to build this dashboard before? If so, why didn’t they succeed? * What are the biggest nagging issues you have currently getting to the data that matters to you?

complex_prompt.text: Examine the following scenarios for dashboards that are being build. What type of audience is each dashboard being designed for: strategic or tactical audience? Answer strategic or tactical for each point below. Drag and drop the buttons below to the correct box.

concepts.text: Your dashboard is mounted on a wall with metrics practically updating in real-time
Your dashboard is used in quarterly round-table discussions.
Your dashboard is used by a sales force day-to-day.

atoms.text: ## Sample Dashboards for Strategic and Tactical Audiences

## Dashboard for Strategic Audience
The following dashboard does not require the audience to take any immediate action. It is meant more to inform those present in the meeting of information, such as variance year to date and progress over time.

In the following example, the sales are compared to the previous year - information that would not be as useful for a tactical audience, but rather for a strategic audience. There is no actionable information here for a tactical audience. Therefore, the following example is designed for a strategic audience.

## Tactical Audience Dashboard
The following is an example of a dashboard for a tactical audience. It contains information with daily utility, and it is operationalized within the team. It includes daily time logs, budget burndown. The days can provide an indication to the team if they are on target to meet their date timeline.

atoms.title: text about audience dimensions
atoms.text:
## Dimensions of Target Audience 1. Strategic vs. Tactical 2. Years of experience 3. Level of motivation 4. Technical expertise
It is important to know if our audience can hold a conversation accurately discussing statistics or do we need to communicate more generally. This impacts the level of details we add to the dashboard. 5. Importance of design
Think about whether the design guidelines are important for the brand and how it is included and paid attention to in the dashboard. This should inform how you approach the design element of your dashboard. __Again, to start you off, these are some questions to consider asking the stakeholder about Design:__ #### Design * What devices will the dashboard be viewed on most frequently? * Do you have style guides we can use? * Can you provide examples of dashboards or the style you would like this dashboard to imitate? #### Cultural background * Be culturally sensitive when adding colors and specific designs. Red can have a negative connotation in some cultures. There can be script differences (e.g., Arabic scripts are written left to right). You can’t avoid all of these, but it helps to know where your audience is coming from so you can design a dashboard that is culturally sensitive.

atoms.title: pain points text
atoms.text:
## Pain Points
__ To get at why the numbers in the dashboard matter for the audience, you need to delve into why these numbers are relevant for your audience. __

We can get to the bottom of it with questions like the following?
* What keeps you up at night?
 * Are the investors going to like our pitch?
 * Are we making the right inventory stocking levels so that we don’t run out of product?
* What one problem is solved would make the biggest positive impact?
 * Increasing the competitiveness of our sales team with a live dashboard hung over their desks
 * Making sure we are keeping our customers happier than all of the competition
* What other questions need to be answered to answer the main question?
 * If I need to restock the inventory what other supplier choices do we have?
 * How well is the competition serving their customers?
* What kind of metric are we looking at? 
 *  Binary (Y/N), trend, range
 * Do we need to notify the supplier with an alert to reorder as soon as inventory hits a certain level?
 * How is customer satisfaction being measured? Is this an industry standard something specific to us?
* What key decisions will this dashboard support?
* What is the most important question this dashboard can answer?
* What pain is this dashboard meant to address?
* What unique value do you have the dashboard provides you and/or your team?

atoms.title: instructions- Exercise 2
atoms.text:
##  Exercise 2: Order the priorities for your audience.
####  Instructions:
You are creating a dashboard for a Bachelor of Marketing student who is actively choosing classes for their upcoming semester. 
1. Give yourself a full 10 minutes to create a list of priorities a student in this situation would think through in order to make a well informed course selection.
2. Once you have this list choose a primary motivating factor and a secondary motivating factor to influence the order of your list.

### Reference material:
We also recommend that you review the [Ben Shneiderman case study](https://www.cs.umd.edu/~ben/papers/Shneiderman1996eyes.pdf)

atoms.title: ND197 C02 L01 A44 Data V2

atoms.text:
## Get Details! This point cannot be emphasized enough. If the stakeholders are only providing you with high-level descriptions like “we want to improve” or “get better” or “capture new market share” you need to drive them to measurable specifics that quantify what “better” means for their business or how you might be able to quantify their “current market share vs. their futures share” so you can compare one to another in a way the audience can act on. So employ user research methods to drive them to define __what measureable specifics__ means for them? Here are some additional online resources that you can look into that describe user research methods that can be effective:
  1. [Individual interviews from Usability.gov](https://www.usability.gov/how-to-and-tools/methods/individual-interviews.html)
  2. [Interaction Design Foundation](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/user-interviews) can be a good resource too #### Again, to start you off, these are some questions to consider asking the stakeholder: #### Data * How old can the data be and still be useful? * What’s the relevant timeline of the data? * Is there sensitive information we need to prevent certain people from seeing?
    #### Form * What devices will the dashboard be viewed on most frequently? * Do you have style guides we can use? * Can you provide examples of dashboards or the style you would like this dashboard to imitate?

atoms.title: exercise 3
atoms.text:
## Exercise 3: Pick the Data Points From the Questions

#### Instructions
Point out the data required to answer the questions below.

1. What’s our year-over-year % change of ecotourism visitorship in Costa Rica?
2. How long will the coffee shop's current inventory last before another order is needed?
3. Given our current conversion rate, how many more leads should be captured in order to hit my quota?

# Solution

1. What’s our year-over-year % change of ecotourism visitorship in Costa Rica?
   * **Year-over-year % change**: You’ll need the visitorship of this year and the previous
   * ** Ecotourism visitorship**: You will need the visitorship numbers, specifically Ecotourism in Costa Rica

2. How long will the coffee shop's current inventory last before another order is needed?
   * **Current inventory**: We’ll need the current inventory level.
   * **Consumption rate (or demand)**: We’ll need to know this in order to how quickly we’re working through our current coffee stock.
   * **Lead time**: We need to know this coupled with our consumption rate in order to know when to place another order before we run out of stock.

3. Given our current conversion rate, how many more leads should be captured in order to hit my quota?
   * **Conversion rate**: What is our current conversion rate and how is it calculated?
   * **Quota**: What is your sales quota?
   * **Leads captured**: What does it mean to capture a lead?

# Key Ingredients of our SOW

1. Explicitly call out your target audience
 * Name, department, team, etc.

2. Paraphrase the primary pain point being addressed by this dashboard
 * This dashboard is being designed to increase the company's market share by increasing the competitiveness among sales staff to convert more leads into paying customers.

3. Clearly define the data that will be used in this dashboard
 * We are using data warehouse X or datasources Y, Z from start date to end date. Defined metrics include… Metrics yet to be defined are… Data assumptions are this, that and the other.

atoms.title: exercise 4
atoms.text:
## Instructions:
Let’s build on Exercise 2 where you created a list of priorities for building a dashboard for a Bachelor of Marketing student. Again, the objective of the dashboard is to help students choose classes for their upcoming semester.

Now your objective is to create a __Statement of Work__. Your Statement of Work should include the following details: 
1. Audience attributes
2. Motivations
3. Necessary data

__Constraints:__
*  The primary motivation of this audience is to receive the highest quality teaching possible, but they do hold a job while attending school so the classes have to fit within their available time. 
* They do not want to take any more than 5 classes, but no less than 4.

atoms.title: Solution_Exercise 4
atoms.text:
# Solution

### Audience attributes
University student working their way through, while keeping the quality of their marketing curriculum top of mind.

### Motivations
This student has tuition to pay, but they’re focused on getting the best education possible.

### Data
1. Necessary:
 * Work schedule
 * Time to get to work from class
 * Importance of course subject matter for a marketing student
 * Area of marketing they’d like to focus
 * Some sort of teacher quality score which could be:
     * Recommendations
     * Past student reviews
     * Awards the teacher has received

2. Optional
 * Number of classes they’d like to take
 * Time of day preference
 * Etc.

### In summary
Our dashboard will provide this stellar student with a list of courses that fit their work schedule, ranked by course quality.
